Authors:
Carolina Delfini, Juan Manuel Acosta, Vinicius Castro
Souza, Fernando Omar Zuloaga
Title:
Phylogenetic relationships in the group Caespitosa of
Paspalum L. (Poaceae, Panicoideae, Paspaleae)
Journal: Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciências
Keywords:
ETS, Gramineae, informal groups, ndhF, rpl16, systematics,
taxonomy, trnH-psbA
Abstract:
Paspalum L. is one of richest genera within Poaceae,
including nearly 350 species, mostly native to the Americas. The genus
has been divided generally into four subgenera, 27 sections and about 30
informal groups, based exclusively on morphological features. The group
Caespitosa comprises a complex of 1315 perennial species characterized
by its mostly caespitose habit, culms simple or occasionally with a
single branch, inflorescences pauci to pluriracemose, and spikelets
usually ellipsoid. Previous molecular phylogenetic studies have
suggested that the group Caespitosa might not be monophyletic but, did
not analyze a large enough sample of taxa for a meaningful conclusion.
In this study, we increased the number of species sampled (13 Caespitosa
species) and sequenced four DNA regions (ETS, ndhF, rpl16, and
trnH-psbA). We tested whether Caespitosa, as traditionally
circumscribed, does not represent a natural group and analyzed its
relationships using parsimony, likelihood, and Bayesian inference. Our
findings show the group Caespitosa is polyphyletic, with its species
distributed in seven moderately to strongly supported clades. All clades
are morphologically distinctive, not correlated with the existing
infrageneric classification, and one is associated with geographic
isolation. The relationships between some clades and species are unclear
and have also been discussed here.
